entry.title: Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing
entry.content:
Integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing

Follow the below blog from Nageshcaparthy and want to highlight couple of things which this blog didn’t cover and couple of changes were needed in SAP help document which is informed to SAP product team during my interaction.

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-integration-with-sap-ariba-setup-guide/ba-p/14240003

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/integrating-joule-with-sap/integration-with-sap-ariba

We should consider 2 scenarios

  1. Customers who have already integrated SAP Ariba with SSO.
  2. Those who are 1st time implementing SAP Ariba with SSO and integrating with SAP Joule

Scenario 1:

Since we belong in this category I want to share changes observed during this whole process and my experience through this article.

Activation of Joule and formations were already in place and SAP Successfactor integration completed successfully.

Comparing the steps from the blog and at the same time highlighting the changes

  1. Steps involved during this integration
  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services (ICM Process) – completed
  2. OAuth Credentials for CDM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal) – We needed not only these keys but SCIM API for User and Group Master Data.
  3. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from SAP Ariba Applications to IAS
    1. Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System
    2. Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System
  4. Integrating Joule
  • Have an existing Joule setup, and a formation has been created
  1. Post-integration checks
  • Validate Application List
  • Validate the Attributes
  • Trusted Domains
  • Conditional Authentication
  1. Destination Setup
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations
    1. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations – DT
    2. SAP Ariba Sourcing Destinations – RT
  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider 
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions
  • Channel Updates
  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Configure the Source System
  • Configure Target Systems
    • SAP Ariba Sourcing – Target
    • Run Sync Job

During my session along with SAP Development team it was clarified that the users sync from IAS to Ariba were not required as it was not required since SAP Ariba was already integrated with IAS for SSO and users in both were already in Sync.

please read the disclaimer from referred blog.

  1. SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services

since this configuration is already in place and ensured that joule activation was done using the same IAS tenant which was used earlier for integration with SAP Successfactor and the same should be used for other LOB’s. If other LOBs are configured with different IAS tenants then you may have to migrate them to this IAS tenant it will be really challenging. As highlighted in my earlier blog this requires proper planning for unification of all the SAP LOBs into a single IAS tenant.

We had details discussion with SAP Team about the critical aspect of GUID (SCIM ID) – All along I had an impression that GUID were required for user authentication and conversations and it requires to send this information from IAS to Ariba which was not required as Ariba doesn’t depend on it entirely rather it uses other attributes of the user like email ID and Login name even though Ariba uses S4HANA in the backend it is completely controlled from Application side.

 The question will arise what about S4HANA either cloud or on-premise systems to be integrated with Joule how the GUID will be taken care of. It entirely depends on the way the users from IAS to these LOBs are sync. Once we achieved it part of Task center implementation is that the GUID of uses from IAS were updated into S4HANA on premise (existing setup) using BADI. You can refer to any blog or online information you will find the details.

As per the blog we changed the url from ondemand.com to cloud.sap with the help of Ariba team since as customer you don’t have an option to change it.

Since already we had the existing setup of Ariba integration with IAS there are no source and target systems created in IDP.

Thankfully the blog has provided the json files for source system and target system which we used and manually created them for replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS.

In the blog and in help document it is mentioned that once the above step is completed we should have the necessary bundled applications, Source, target systems in IAS which didn’t happen in our case since we already had the necessary application defined manually for integration of Ariba with IAS. I recommend this to be included in any of the blogs or in the help document so that customer is aware of it.

Sourcing system

Target system

  1. OAuth Credentials for SCIM API (SAP Ariba Developer Portal)

Follow the steps mentioned in the blog and the difference is we faced issue with replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS and after session with Ariba team advised us to create SCIM API in place CDM API created using workzone CDM Content and these details are meant to use in source system of users and groups replication from IAS to Workzone. The details of SCIM API requested through SAP Ariba Development Portal. It is possible to get both API’s by creating the incident as we didn’t find the workzone CDM API in the portal and it is created and sent to us by Ariba team except creation of secret which can be done by the administrator of portal.

3.1 Create Ariba to IAS User Sync - Source System

Created the source system using the json files provided in the blog and used the SCIM API created earlier in the Development portal.

3.2 Create Ariba to IAS User - Target System

The user and password are taken from a system user created in the administrator console with client ID and secret by providing only the necessary auth. to manage users and groups.

Followed other recommendations provided in the blog to remove some property parameters

Replication of users and groups from Ariba to IAS is successful. check the below details from provisioning logs.

Note: Moment of caution again don’t sync user replication from IAS to Ariba which is not required it may differ in terms of specific cases and would advise to take the help of Ariba team.

  1. Integrating Joule

As we already had the existing setup of joule with formations ready we added the Ariba realm and ended with the issue below. Not providing complete details as they are already covered in the blog.

Synchronization was failing as it was unable to identify already created application in IAS. After weeks long investigation by Joule and Ariba product development team they created one more application other than already existing one added the missing client ID inside the attributes of the application, and we were able to add the Ariba tenant successfully into the formation.

Production development still they are trying to figure out the issue and hopefully in subsequent release the process will identify the existing application in IAS which will create the necessary bundle application under the main application.

After successfully adding the Ariba tenant still joule icon was not appearing in the Ariba tenant and further it was resolved by Ariba team after activating feature toggles in Ariba tenant.

  1. Post-integration checks

Follow the validation of attributes, application, Changes in the trusted domain, Conditional authentication at IAS as mentioned in the blog.

  1. Destination Setup

Follow and create destination of Design time and runtime as mentioned in the blog and use the files provided in github.

https://github.com/SAP-samples/btp-onboarding/tree/main/docs/Joule-with-SAP-Ariba/JSON-Files

  1. SAP Build Work Zone - Content Provider
  • Content Provider for SAP Ariba Sourcing Solutions

Following the steps mentioned in the blog and initial update will fail since still users and groups were not replicated from IAS to Ariba.

  1. Configure Identity Provisioning Service from IAS to SAP Build Work Zone

We had issue with creation of source system in IDP for replication of users and groups ( As per the blog it should create automatically once the IAS tenant is added in to ICM which didn’t create in our case) json files were also missing in the blog. Requested the product development to add them into the same github repository.

Followed the help document to create the source and target systems in IDP.

Execution of sync job should be successful once you ensured that property parameters in both source and target systems are properly maintained.

Now if a refresh is done for SAP Ariba strategic sourcing in Workzone it should be updated successfully.

verify whether the groups are assigned to the users..

I had an interesting discussion with SAP Product team why not Ariba also follows the same way users and groups are replicated from SF to WZ during integration of SAP Successfactor with Joule (where they are directly moved from SF to WZ by passing the IAS where IAS is used only for authentication). In Ariba the users and groups are replicated from Ariba-IAS-WZ. The explanation is that both products are different in the way they interact with BTP. SF is part of BTP whereas Ariba is completely different SAAS product.

 

  1. Joule Test Scenarios

Follow the use cases from the below link. Test each case end to end understand all the scenarios application like Informational, Transactional, Navigational.

Note that beyond the scenarios what are explained and configured to work in Joule don’t execute in you natural language as you won’t find a proper response.

Each interaction user make with joule and response received will be treated as one token and as I mentioned in my earlier blog “Ariba integration with SAP successfactor “you are entitled for fixed number messages free and after that you will be charged so understanding the scenarios and educating the business users adhering to it is critical as of now. Not sure if SAP increases the number of messages free.

https://help.sap.com/docs/joule/capabilities-guide/joule-in-sap-ariba-solutions

 

Conclusion: The Next Generation of Procurement

The integration of SAP Joule AI Copilot with SAP Ariba Sourcing is a significant step toward an AI-driven, friction-less procurement process. This implementation journey, especially for customers with existing SSO configurations, underscores that while official documentation is really useful but it requires changes for both scenarios mentioned.

Key Takeaways and Future Focus

This experience highlights several vital points for organizations embarking on this integration:

  • IAS Unification: The seamless integration of Joule across multiple Line of Business (LOB) applications, like SuccessFactors and Ariba, hinges on the unification of all LOBs to a single SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) tenant. This prevents complex migration challenges and ensures a cohesive user experience.

  • User Sync: For customers already integrated via SSO, the blog's requirement for a separate IAS-to-Ariba user sync can be potentially eliminated or simplified, as Ariba primarily relies on existing attributes like email and login name for authentication, not the GUID/SCIM ID for conversation context, which is the main dependency for other applications like S4HANA, SuccessFactors and SAP concur.

  • Beyond the Standard API: The need to request the SCIM API in addition to the standard OAuth Credentials (CDM API) for user and group replication from Ariba to IAS is a practical detail that requires a proactive approach with the SAP Ariba development team.

  • The Maturing Platform: The initial issues faced with the Joule application identification in IAS and the subsequent need for Ariba team intervention to activate feature toggles demonstrate that the Joule integration architecture, while robust, is still actively maturing. Future releases are expected to streamline the automatic identification and bundling of applications within IAS.

In summary, this integration has successfully delivered the conversational and transactional capabilities of the Joule AI Copilot into the SAP Ariba Sourcing landscape. As SAP continues to invest in generative AI, understanding these practical implementation insights will be crucial for other enterprises to achieve a truly unified, intelligent, and highly efficient procurement experience while maximizing the value of their existing SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: About Manufacturing-X and How to Integrate It with SAP Digital Manufacturing Execution using SAP DSI
entry.content:
Introduction

The manufacturing industry is transforming from isolated enterprise systems to connected, data-driven ecosystems. Companies no longer work alone — they collaborate with suppliers, customers, and partners to build intelligent, transparent, and resilient supply networks.

SAP’s Manufacturing-X is the initiative that makes this transformation real. It enables secure, governed, and standardized data exchange between companies, ensuring data sovereignty and trust.

In this blog, we’ll explore:

  • What Manufacturing-X is and why it matters
  • The role of SAP Data Space Integration (DSI) in implementing these principles
  • How SAP Digital Manufacturing customers can exchange data in decentralized manner using Data Space. 

What Is Manufacturing-X?

Manufacturing-X is SAP’s strategic vision to digitalize the mechanical and discrete manufacturing industries through cross-company collaboration and governed data sharing where trust and compliance are embedded by design.

Core Principles

  • Interoperability: Connect systems across companies using shared standards.
  • Data Sovereignty: Participants control what they share and under what conditions.
  • Transparency: Provide end-to-end visibility across engineering, production, and service.
  • Ecosystem Collaboration: Create value by securely sharing manufacturing data between OEMs, suppliers, and customers.

Now let's expand into one of the well known projects called Catena-X developed by the automotive and industrial community.

Catena-X Components

  1. Trusted Provider Layer: Handles identity, authentication, and secure transport (often implemented through Cofinity-X).
  2. Standards & Governance Layer: Defines semantics, policies, and rules for compliant data exchange.

Each participant in a Catena-X data space can act as a provider (sharing data) or consumer (accessing data). The governance model ensures that all data is exchanged under clearly defined, machine-readable contracts and policies.

Data Space Integration (DSI): The Technical Enabler

SAP’s Data Space Integration (DSI), part of the SAP Integration Suite, operationalizes these concepts. It offers a simple integration of SAP and non-SAP applications as well as a harmonized and intuitive way to configure and monitor the data exchange within a data space leveraging SAP Integration Suite.

According to SAP Help, DSI provides an extensible framework for governed, traceable, and policy-driven data exchange across company boundaries.

DSI Core Capabilities

Capability

Description

Policy & Contract Management

Define who can access what data, for what purpose, and under what rules.

Semantic Mapping & Transformation

Translate between different data models and formats.

Connector Infrastructure

Integrate with SAP and non-SAP systems using existing adapters.

Identity & Access Management

Manage authentication and authorization securely.

Monitoring & Audit Logging

Trace every exchange for compliance.

Consent & Revocation Handling

Allow participants to modify or revoke sharing agreements dynamically.

DSI is the governance and execution layer of Manufacturing-X — it ensures that each data exchange follows policies and contracts defined between the parties.

Understanding “Asset” in Manufacturing-X

In Manufacturing-X, an Asset represents a set of data, not a physical object.
It’s a governed digital construct whose attributes depend on the data space context.

Asset is Asset — but its data representation changes depending on the data space.

For example:

  • In a production data space, an asset includes process data, machine parameters, and batch context.
  • In a maintenance data space, it represents as-built configurations and service records etc.
  • In a sustainability data space, it contains material composition or carbon footprint.

Each data space defines its own semantic model and policies, and DSI ensures these rules are respected when the asset data moves between spaces.

How Assets Are Shared: From Policy to Agreement

Asset data is never shared freely. It is governed through a contractual lifecycle that defines what can be shared, with whom, and under what policies.

The following diagram (from DSI documentation) illustrates this process:


Step-by-Step Explanation

  1. Asset and Policy Definition
    The provider defines the asset (data set) and the policy (usage and access conditions).
  2. Contract Definition
    The asset and policy are combined into a contract definition — describing what data is available and the rules for sharing it.
  3. Contract Offer
    The provider publishes this contract as an offer to potential consumers in the data space.
  4. Contract Negotiation
    Provider and consumer negotiate terms — adjusting policies or scopes as needed.
  5. Contract Agreement
    Once finalized, a contract agreement is created. Only then does the actual data exchange occur.
  6. Data Exchange Execution
    Data is shared securely via DSI and trusted connectors (e.g., Cofinity-X). Policies are automatically enforced — such as data masking, anonymization, or expiry.

This lifecycle ensures data sovereignty — every shared data set is traceable, compliant, and revocable.

Manufacturing-X and SAP Digital Manufacturing Integration

Now let’s see how Manufacturing-X integrates with SAP Digital Manufacturing Execution (SAP DM).

SAP DM is the execution layer on the shop floor, where production data is generated in real time. Manufacturing-X adds the cross-company data-exchange capability, allowing this data to be securely shared beyond enterprise boundaries.

Integration Architecture

  1. SAP DM produces operational data (e.g., WIP data, as-built structures, quality metrics, production events).
  2. DSI, running in SAP Integration Suite, acts as the governance and policy-enforcement layer.
  3. Catena-X connectors / Cofinity-X handle the trusted transfer and authentication.
  4. External systems or partners consume the data in their own data spaces, subject to agreed policies.

Integration Scenarios

1. Direct Customer-to-Customer Data Exchange

Scenario: Two SAP DM customers want to share production data without modifying DM systems by just sharing the endpoint between them.

Flow:

* Each participant connects SAP DM to DSI via standard adapters.

* Provider defines an asset and policy in DSI (e.g., “share quality KPIs weekly” or “share Plant WIP Data weekly”, or “share an SFC WIP Data” ).

* Consumer negotiates and accepts a contract.

* DSI transfers data securely using Catena-X protocols.

Benefit: Trusted exchange between partners — no custom development in SAP DM.

2. Integration with SAP DM Business Processes using custom development

Scenario: When developing an electric vehicle (EV), manufacturers must integrate several advanced components, including specialized chips sourced from external supplier plants. This scenario explores a real workflow found in an automotive manufacturing environment, where production continuity and just-in-time supply chain principles are critical. 

EV Manufacturing workflow Example: In this case, the Shop Floor Control (SFC) for the EV is structured around three major operations:

Battery Module Fabrication: The process begins with the assembly of battery modules, which can proceed independently of other components and often initiates the parent SFC workflow.

Chip Embedding: At this stage, the production is paused ("Hold" status in SFC) until the arrival of the specialized chip from a supplier plant. Once the chip is delivered, it undergoes thorough incoming inspection and testing to ensure quality and functionality before embedding into the vehicle’s electronics or battery cells.

Main Assembly: Upon successful embedding and validation of the chip, the main assembly of the EV resumes. This ensures seamless integration of key electronic features and maximizes operational efficiency.

Production Planning and Just-in-Time Supply: While most EV components can be staged and processed ahead of time, the chip embedding operation relies on just-in-time delivery to minimize idle time and storage costs. Production planners must synchronize supplier shipments and quality inspections with the internal manufacturing schedule to reduce bottlenecks and optimize throughput.

This sample has documented including configuration in SAP DM Github Sample; please refer it for more details and source code implementation. Please note that this sample has been implemented using POD 2.0 (Beta) to demonstrate how easy it is to build custom screens without writing much code in SAP DM using POD 2.0(Beta) framework. But the same sample could be also implemented using POD 1.0/1.1 framework.

Below are some preview from the sample implementation.

Customer Production Operator Dashboard displaying supplier inventory status: 

Supplier Contract consisting of Asset, Access Policy and Usage Policy: 

Customer CPI package to Negotiate and Access Asset:

Implementation Notes

  • DSI integrations are delivered as CPI (Cloud Integration Suite) flows.
  • SAP DM communicates with DSI using REST/OData APIs.
  • Extensions and user exits in SAP DM are used to trigger data-exchange logic.
  • All monitoring and policy enforcement are handled in Integration Suite.

This design keeps SAP DM “clean core” while enabling secure collaboration.

Conclusion

Manufacturing-X brings together trust, standards, and interoperability for the digital manufacturing ecosystem.

By combining:

  • Catena-X (the industry framework),
  • Data Space Integration (DSI) (the SAP implementation layer), and
  • SAP Digital Manufacturing Execution (the operational backbone),

organizations can exchange data securely, with clear governance and full control.

Our sample/demo illustrates how this works in practice:

  1. Customer-to-customer data exchange, and
  2. Integration with SAP DM business processes using Custom Development.

Together, these patterns show that Manufacturing-X isn’t just a vision — it’s a working reality powered by SAP technologies.

✅Recommended reading:

  • SAP Help: Data Space Integration
  • Factory-X: How SAP Is Driving the Digitalization of Mechanical Engineering (SAP News Blog)
  • Catena-X
  • Sample link

entry.title: M3682 - Batch & of material & is already locked by & in MIGO
entry.content:
Dear all, 
could you please help us to solve the following problem in S4 Hana / GUI. 
Issue: We are only for displaying of a material document in MIGO / S4 (gui) and parallel at the same time we want to post a goods movement with the same material and batch by MIGO but we get the error message "M3682 - Batch & of material & is already locked by & in MIGO." The current batch seems to be blocked through the displaying mode of MIGO.
What is the reason for and what kind of customizing settings should be used in the system to be posted a goods movements by MIGO under displaying a material document by MIGO? 

Thanks in advance!

Regards,

János

entry.title: Re: TA (Talent Admin ) Role in Performance Goal Plan Template
entry.content: TA permissions apply mainly to Development Goals, not Performance Goal Plans, which is why adding write access in the Performance Goal Plan XML doesn’t work. To give TA write access for performance goals, you’ll need to adjust Role-Based Permissions (RBP) or remap roles in the template, since TA isn’t natively supported there.

entry.title: Re: TA (Talent Admin ) Role in Performance Goal Plan Temp...
entry.content:
Hello Mansi,

TA also should have Goal Plan access permission in Manage Permission Roles.

It is doesn't work with both XML and Permission Role permissions, then you could set TA like a Matrix Manager/HR Manager - one of the options in Job Relationships. This way TA will be able to conduct the permissions in XML. This is what I do for Project Managers/HRBP and other additional roles. It doesn't work only by one of the system role /EH/, without the Job Relationship setup. 

BR,

Petya

entry.title: Re: 是否能导入财务的历史数据#CoE#MRAS How to upload historical financ...
entry.content:
Dear @leah2,

In a Greenfield Public Cloud scenario, SAP standard approach is:

  1. Historical G/L balances (aggregated)
    • Via migration object FI Historical balance in the Migrate Your Data Migration Cockpit app.

 

More details below from SAP Community and SAP Note:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/historical-balances-migration-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13580309

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3661053

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/886e1b9bf25245d093a98e0c635818e5.html

  1. Assets with history
    • With the asset migration objects you can load:
      • Asset master data
      • Fixed asset - Postings

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/20607b6de19a4d34a41b0abec6186b01.html

So, yes you can bring financial history but mainly as aggregated balances, not every document.

Summary:

  • Yes, you can import financial history in a Greenfield Public Cloud
    • Typically: FI – Historical balance (historical balances), opening balances, open items, and asset history.
  • No, you cannot fully reload every old FI document as if all years had been originally posted for example in another system SAP

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Demystifying TDC and TDR – What You Need to Know
entry.content:
Many of you have reached out to understand the difference between TDC and TDR, especially to gain clarity on which option to choose as part of the post-3SL conversion activity. To address this, I’m introducing a new blog that demystifies TDC and TDR, providing you with all the insights and capabilities you need to make the best decision for your test environment.

We have seen how data migration is supported during 3SL conversion in our earlier blog -Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community. We have also seen how Test Data Conversion (TDC) will come handy and accelerate the test system readiness with valid, depersonalised test data and system configurations from Previous quality tenant in blog - Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community. In blog  Test Data Refresh: Enhancing test tenant quality - SAP Community we have gained a clear understanding on the Test Data Refresh (TDR), its purpose, and value added as part of 3 SL post conversion journey.  

 Now, with both TDC and TDR available as data migration services, a natural question arises: 

“If both services support data migration, how do we decide which one to use?” 

 In this blog, we’ll explore the key differences between TDC and TDR and highlight a few important considerations that will help you determine which service best fits your data migration needs. 

 

TDC and TDR Comparison: 

 

Feature 

Test Data Conversion 

Test Data Refresh  

Definition 

Data is migrated from Development tenant to new test tenant 

Data is migrated from Production tenant to new test tenant 

Source for Data Migration 

Development tenant  

Production tenant. 

Available to  

S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3 SL conversion customers 

All S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers 

Usage 

One time 

Multiple time  

Subscription-based 

No 

Yes 

Data migration scope includes 

  • Master data 
  • Transactional data 
  • System configuration data 
  • Historical test data 
  • Master data 
  • Transactional data 

 

Key contribution 

Accelerate Test tenant readiness 

Enhance test data quality from ongoing data. 

Pre- requisites 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance.   
  3. Content Version Alignment.   
  4. Extension Readiness.  
  5. Clean Development transport Queue.  
  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance.   
  3. Content Version Alignment.   
  4. Extension Readiness.  
  5. Clean Production transport Queue.  

 

Depersonalization feature 

Optional 

Optional 

Calendar based slots 

Yes 

Yes 

 

Conclusion: 

Throughout this blog series, we’ve explored the data migration services available to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers, focusing on their scope, capabilities, and distinct roles in the 3-System Landscape post conversion activities. 

We began by understanding how data migration is supported during the 3SL conversion, followed by a deep dive into Test Data Conversion (TDC) — an accelerator that enables early test system readiness with valid, depersonalized data and configurations. we examined Test Data Refresh (TDR), a powerful service that ensures ongoing test data quality by replicating production-like data into the test tenant. 

Together, TDC and TDR form a complementary framework: 

  • TDC is ideal for initial test system setup post-conversion. 
  • TDR supports ongoing test data refreshes to maintain test system relevance and accuracy. 

We hope this series has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of these services and how they contribute to a robust, efficient, and secure testing environment in your SAP S/4HANA Cloud journey. 

 

 Reference: 

For more details about the Handle Your Extensions app and its use, refer to the Blog - Handle Your Extensions - test data refresh.  

  • Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community
  • Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: OUTSTANDING CAPITAL BALANCE TO BE AMORTIZED (FIXED AS...
entry.content:
Dear @facundo_orekait,

As per my understanding after reading the issue, Let’s break this down step by step so you can pinpoint whether this is a configuration issue or a posting issue in SAP Fixed Assets. looks like what's happening now is acquisition value and accumulated depreciation are posting correctly, so your asset master data and depreciation areas are fine. The net book value (NBV) — acquisition minus accumulated depreciation — is showing under “WITHOUT ASSIGNMENT” in the Balance Sheet.

This usually means SAP couldn’t find a proper Financial Statement Version (FSV) assignment for the account being used, so it drops the balance into the “without assignment” bucket.

Please check these possible causes.

1. Account Determination setup
In SAP Asset Accounting, each asset transaction (acquisition, depreciation, retirement, etc.) is linked to a G/L account via Account Determination. If the NBV account (or clearing account) is incorrectly mapped, SAP will still post, but the Balance Sheet won’t know where to show it.
Check the AO90 configuration (Account Determination for Asset Accounting) and ensure the right G/L accounts are assigned for 1)Acquisition, 2)Accumulated depreciation, 3)Retirement, 4)Clearing accounts.

2. Financial Statement Version (FSV) mapping
Even if the G/L accounts are correct, they must be assigned to the right nodes in the Balance Sheet structure. If the NBV-related account isn’t mapped in the FSV, SAP will push it to “Without Assignment.”
Go to OB58 (Assign Accounts to FSV) and verify that the account is linked to the correct Balance Sheet item.

3. Upload process
If you used direct G/L postings during the upload instead of asset transactions (e.g., FB01 instead of ABZON/AB01), SAP might not recognize the postings as asset-related. This can cause mismatches between Asset Accounting and FI.

Hope you can get the issue fixed by above explanation.

entry.title: Issue in S/4HANA → SAP Sales Cloud v2 Integration: Wrong Sender/Receiver System IDs Passed
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

we are currently implementing the standard integration between SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 using the official SAP Integration Suite package:

“SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANA”
(in particular the iFlow “Replicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S/4HANA”)

During our setup we noticed a behavior that appears to be incorrect or at least not documented. The iFLow in SAP Standard expects an IDOC Structure (here message type COD_REPLICATE_SALES_ORDER)

What we observed

When S/4HANA sends sales order replication data to SAP Integration Suite, it uses the following system identifiers:

  • Sender system: S4HCLNT100

  • Receiver system: MY1001354

These are the classical Logical System names.

However, SAP Sales Cloud v2 expects the system identifiers that are defined in the Communication System setup inside Sales Cloud v2, for example:

  • Sender system: S4H_100

  • Receiver system: sap_cloud_crm_my1001354

Because of this mismatch, the standard iFlow fails unless we manually change the mapping inside the iFlow.
After adjusting the mapping, the messages are processed correctly.

Why this is confusing

In the Sales Cloud v2 integration:

  • There is no place in S/4HANA where these system IDs can be adapted specifically for Sales Cloud v2.

  • The standard content in SAP Integration Suite does not expose parameters to override sender/receiver IDs.

  • The documentation does not mention any required mapping.

This means:
The standard iFlow expects the Sales Cloud v2 Communication System IDs, but S/4HANA always sends Logical System IDs.

So the iFlow and the S/4HANA standard do not match each other out-of-the-box.

💬 Our question to the community

Is this behavior expected?
Or is this a gap/bug in the standard integration?

Also:
Is there any hidden configuration in S/4HANA to control which system identifiers are passed to the iFlow?
We could not find any.

At the moment, we had to modify the iFlow (which we would prefer to avoid), and we’d like to know:

  • Does SAP plan to adjust the integration content?

  • Or have other customers found a clean configuration-based solution?

Any guidance, insights, or experiences would be highly appreciated. 😊

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Upload storage bin sorting does not work /SCWM/SRTUP...
entry.content:
While uploading the sort for the bins, system checks the activity area PAL and then the 1st storage type assigned to it in the sequence. (Check config - Assign Storage Bins to Activity Areas, to find the sequence).

Probably the reason could be the 1st storage type assigned to this activity area does not have any bin in the system. this is a standard bug in the system. 

Regards,

Nikkhil Shetty

entry.title: Re: No batch input data for screen SAPLMGMM 0060Message N...
entry.content:
It could be due to the below reasons:

Missing plant data: The template does not include the plant field or the plant assignment is incorrect.
Incorrect recording: If you used a batch input recording, the sequence of screens does not match the data you are uploading.
Field mapping issue: In LSMW, the source fields are not mapped correctly to the target fields (e.g., MARC table for plant-specific data).
Dynamic screen flow: Material master screens vary depending on the views selected (Basic Data, Plant Data, Sales, Purchasing, etc.). If your recording didn’t capture the plant-specific screen, the batch input will fail.

To fix this, perform the following:

Check your recording 
Ensure you recorded MM01/MM02 with the correct sequence of views (including Plant Data/Storage, Purchasing, MRP, etc.). If the plant screen wasn’t included, redo the recording.

Verify source file
Make sure your upload file includes the plant field (WERKS) and all mandatory plant-specific fields. Example MARC-WERKS, MARC-DISMM (MRP type), MARC-BESKZ (procurement type), etc.

Field mapping 
Map the source fields to the correct target fields in MARC (plant data). If mapping is missing, the batch input won’t know what to fill.

Maintain default values
If certain plant fields are always the same (e.g., default plant), set them as default values. This avoids missing data errors.

Run in foreground
Execute the batch input in foreground mode. Watch where the system stops, it will show you the exact screen and field that is missing. Add those fields to your source file or adjust the recording.

entry.title: Re: How to change the price condition which is overwritte...
entry.content: I don't think, it will consider only pr00. Just call $SET_PRICING_FACTOR with your custom condition type ZPR6 in the dependency logic. As long as ZPR6 is in the pricing procedure and behaves like a value condition, the factor will apply. In your configuration dependency procedure/function, instead of calling $SET_PRICING_FACTOR PR00, you call it with ZPR6 like $SET_PRICING_FACTOR ZPR6 = 1.2

entry.title: How to get recorded working time or working days of timesheet in time off take rule?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We have time tracking enabled instance.

We have a requirement in employee central time off.

We have a group of employees who works continuously for 50 days without week offs. After working continuously for 48 to 50 days, then they will apply for a leave of 10 days, for that we have a leave type called "work break". 

If the employee failed to complete at least 48 days of work then system should restrict them while applying the leave.

Example:- If the employee wish to request leave from 1st November 2025 for 10 days, then that employee has to work for 48 to 50 days before the start date of the leave. then only the employee can request leave from 1st Nov 2025 to 10th Nov 2025. If the employee failed to work minimum 48 days before 1st Nov 2025 as per work schedule, then system should restrict the employee while requesting "Work Break Leave".

As we have timesheet implemented, the attendance data of the employee is getting recorded in the timesheet.

Please suggest me that how can I read the recorded working time or working days data from the timesheet data of the employee by using the time off take rule to check the attendance recorded in the period from (-50 days of 1st Nov 2025) to (1st Nov 2025).

Many Thanks

SAH

entry.title: How can I save designated documents in a OneDrive Shared Folder if I don' want to print or email
entry.content:
You would like to save i.e. all customer invoices instead of printing or emailing in a shared OneDrive Folder.

This is possible if the windows User has Onedrive assigned you can save the documents in question and also share the Onedrive Folder with the Users in question.

Save to File Path i.e. C:\Users\Your User \OneDrive\CPM One drive Test 2025

 

This works for all documents with printing output.

 

This setup requires the CPM (Cloud Print Manager for SAP Business ByDesign)

entry.title: Re: Put Component Quantity field as mandatory at Maintena...
entry.content:
Hello , This is the BADI you can try EAMS_EVAL_ORDER_DETAILS . 

here is an example code, since you dont have Component details directly available , try the following by reading 

component details using the Order ID 

 

METHOD if_eams_ext_eval_order_details~eval_order_details.

DATA: lt_resb TYPE TABLE OF resb,

          ls_message TYPE ty_s_message.

 

"Read components for the current order

 SELECT * FROM resb INTO TABLE lt_resb WHERE aufnr = order_header-orderid.

LOOP AT lt_resb ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_resb>).

IF <ls_resb-menge> IS INITIAL OR <ls_resb-menge> = 0.

CLEAR ls_message. ls_message-msgid = 'ZPM'.

"Custom message class ls_message-msgno = '001'.

"Message number ls_message-msgty = 'E'.

"Error ls_message-msgv1 = |Quantity is mandatory for component { <ls_resb-matnr> }|.

APPEND ls_message TO messages.

ENDIF.

ENDLOOP.

ENDMETHOD

 

Regards 

SGK

entry.title: Adding Shell Plugin to SAP Fiori CAP Application and Deploying to Cloud Portal Service
entry.content:
Introduction

Shell plugins in SAP Fiori launchpad allow you to extend the standard functionality of the launchpad shell. This comprehensive guide walks you through the process of creating and deploying a shell plugin CAP application to the SAP Cloud Portal service.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Business Application Studio or VS Code with SAP extensions
  • Access to SAP BTP account with Cloud Portal service
  • Basic knowledge of UI5 and CAP development
  • Fiori Generator tools installed

Step 1: Create Basic UI Using Fiori Generator

First, generate a basic Fiori application using the Fiori Generator:

Step 2: Clean Up Generated Files

Delete all files except the following essential ones:

  • manifest.json
  • Component.js
  • index.html
  • i18n folder

Step 3: Modify index.html

Update your index.html file to support the shell plugin configuration:

<!DOCTYPE html>

<html lang="en">

<head>

    <meta charset="UTF-8">

    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">

    <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">

    <title>Shell Plugin</title>

   

    <style>

        html, body, #container, #container-uiarea {

            height: 100%;

            margin: 0;

            padding: 0;

            overflow: hidden;

        }

    </style>

   

    <script

        id="sap-ui-bootstrap"

        src="https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/1.108.4/resources/sap-ui-core.js"

        data-sap-ui-theme="sap_fiori_3"

        data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{"shellplugin": "./"}'

        data-sap-ui-onInit="module:shellplugin/ComponentSupport"

        data-sap-ui-async="true"

        data-sap-ui-preload="async">

    </script>

</head>

<body class="sapUiBody sapUiSizeCompact" id="content">

    <div data-sap-ui-component

         data-name="shellplugin"

         data-id="container"

         data-settings='{"id":"shellplugin"}'

         data-handle-validation="true">

    </div>

</body>

</html>

Step 4: Update Component.js - Change to AppComponent

Modify your Component.js file to change the controller from UIComponent to AppComponent:

sap.ui.define(["sap/fe/core/AppComponent"], function (AppComponent) {

    "use strict";

   

    return AppComponent.extend("shellplugin.Component", {

        metadata: {

            manifest: "json"

        },

       

        init: function () {

            // Call parent init

            AppComponent.prototype.init.apply(this, arguments);

            console.log("✅ Plugin is working!");

           

            // Get DAS service

            const oDAS = this.getShellService("ShellNavigation");

           

            // DAS not available case

            if (!window.das_props_hostname) {

                console.warn("⚠️ DAS not available - das_props_hostname missing");

                return;

            }

           

            console.warn("✅ DAS name not found [das_props_botname missing]!");

           

            this.waitForShellAndAddStyleButton();

        },

       

        waitForShellAndAddStyleButton: function () {

            // DAS properties

            window.das_env =

                "YOUR_ENV_URL";

           

            // Create script tag

            const script = document.createElement("script");

            script.setAttribute("data-bot-name", window.das_props_botname);

            script.setAttribute("data-expander-type", "CUSTOM");

            script.setAttribute("id", "das");

            script.setAttribute("src",

                "data:text/javascript;base64,<YOUR_BASE64_ENCODED_SCRIPT>");

           

            script.onload = () => {

                if (!window.das?.setClientTheme) {

                    console.error("das.setClientTheme not available");

                }

            };

           

            document.head.appendChild(script);

        }

    });

});

Key Changes:

  • Changed from UIComponent to AppComponent
  • Used "use strict" for better code quality
  • Extended plugins.Component in the return statement

Step 5: Write Web Client Bridge Code in Component.js

The web client bridge code (shown above) handles:

  • Shell service integration
  • DAS (Digital Assistant Service) properties configuration
  • Dynamic script loading
  • Client theme management

This code checks for DAS availability and dynamically loads the required scripts for integration.

Step 6: Add Cross Navigation Details in manifest.json

Update your manifest.json to include cross navigation configuration:

{

    "_version": "1.49.0",

    "sap.app": {

        "id": "shellplugin",

        "type": "component",

        "title": "Shell Plugin Application",

        "applicationVersion": {

            "version": "1.0.0"

        }

    },

    "sap.ui5": {

        "rootView": {

            "viewName": "shellplugin.view.App",

            "type": "XML",

            "id": "app"

        },

        "dependencies": {

            "minUI5Version": "1.108.0",

            "libs": {

                "sap.ui.core": {},

                "sap.m": {},

                "sap.ui.layout": {},

                "sap.f": {}

            }

        },

        "contentDensities": {

            "compact": true,

            "cozy": true

        }

    },

    "sap.fiori": {

        "type": "plugin"

    },

    "sap.platform.cf": {

        "oAuthScopes": []

    }

}

Important Properties:

  • Set "type": "plugin" in the sap.fiori section
  • Include necessary UI5 library dependencies
  • Configure application version and ID

Step 7: Add Shell Plugin Details in CommonDataModel.json

Create or update CommonDataModel.json payload:

{

                "appId": "plugins",

                "vizId": "Shell-plugin"

              },

Step 8: Add Bootstrap Details in ushellConfig

Configure the Unified Shell (ushell) in CommonDataModel.json in businessApps:

"bootstrapPlugins": {

                  "BUILT_IN_SUPPORT": {

                    "component": "plugins",

                    "url": "../plugins",

                    "self": {

                      "name": "plugins"

                    }

                  }

                }

              },

Bootstrap Configuration:

  • Define plugin component and URL
  • Set renderer type as RendererExtensions
  • Configure application registration in Fiori Launchpad

Deployment to Cloud Portal Service

Step 1: Build the Application

# Build MTA archive

mbt build

Step 2: Deploy to Cloud Foundry

# Login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

 

# Deploy the mtar file

cf deploy mta_archives/your_app_1.0.0.mtar

Step 3: Configure in Portal Service

  1. Open SAP Cloud Portal service
  2. Navigate to Provider Manager
  3. Add a new Content Provider pointing to your deployed application
  4. Create a new site or update existing site
  5. Add the shell plugin to the site settings
  6. Assign roles to users who need access

Step 4: Test the Plugin

  1. Open your Fiori Launchpad
  2. Check browser console for the "✅ Plugin is working!" message
  3. Verify that the plugin functionality is active

Troubleshooting

Common Issues

Plugin not loading:

  • Check manifest.json has correct "type": "plugin"
  • Verify Component.js extends AppComponent correctly
  • Check browser console for errors

DAS not available:

  • Verify das_props_hostname is set
  • Check script URL in waitForShellAndAddStyleButton
  • Ensure network access to external resources

 

 

Conclusion

You've successfully created and deployed a shell plugin for SAP Fiori launchpad. This plugin extends the standard launchpad functionality and can be customized further based on your business requirements.

Happy Coding! 🚀

entry.title: S/4HANA公有云版的内部ABAP拓展
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

很多人误以为SAP ERP公有云版"阉割"了ABAP开发能力。事实恰恰相反：它不仅保留了ABAP开发的核心能力，还让开发变得更规范、更可靠、更面向未来。

 

SAP如何在ERP公有云版中实现ABAP开发？？

业务现实：

  • 企业需要深度定制来满足特殊业务需求，这是不可避免的。
  • 但传统ABAP扩展方式虽然灵活，却容易导致维护噩梦和升级困难，SAP的内置AI功能更是难以做到开箱即用

在ERP公有云版本中，SAP提供了更智能的开发方式：

  • 关键用户扩展：低代码方式解决大部分的小需求
  • 开发人员扩展：基于ABAP的深度定制，解决复杂需求

重点是：开发人员扩展方式依然是真正的ABAP开发！

 

开发人员拓展方式和传统ABAP代码开发的区别

核心事实：两种方式都是写ABAP代码，区别只是开发规范更严格了

开发活动传统ABAP方式开发人员拓展方式差异说明
开发工具可以采用ADT或内置T-Code必须使用基于Eclipse的ABAP Development Tools（ADT） 
数据模型定义创建数据库表(SE11)创建CDS数据定义和接口视图使用声明式CDS语法，内置元数据注解
业务逻辑实现编写Function Module或Class开发RAP行为定义和行为实现类使用声明式CDS语法，内置元数据注解
服务暴露手动创建RFC/BAPI通过Service Definition自动生成OData服务自动化服务生成，标准OData协议
UI开发开发Dynpro/WebDynpro界面

使用Business Application Studio开发Fiori代码然后部署到S/4HANA中

基于元数据驱动的UI生成

权限控制

手动实现权限检查

通过CDS访问控制和RAP授权

声明式权限模型，集成到框架中

但从拓展可行性角度来看的根本区别是，开发人员拓展方式采用了"白名单"机制：

  • 只能使用SAP官方发布的稳定API和CDS视图
  • 这确保了你的代码在SAP系统升级时不会出问题

所以实际开发前需要确认：

  1. 业务扩展点：确认标准流程提供的BAdI和扩展接口
  2. 数据访问：确认所需业务数据的CDS视图
  3. API可用性：确认所需功能API的发布状态

最后设计目标业务流程，一旦确认完毕，就是标准的ABAP开发流程！

 

实例

接下来以一个完整的ERP公有云开发项目为例，

这个案例将展示完整的'表-逻辑-界面-部署'全栈开发流程，所有代码都运行在S/4HANA系统内部

 

Develop an SAP Fiori App to Trigger Purchase Requisitions API

采购申请应用开发

 

教程概述

这个教程的整体目标是创建一个完整的SAP Fiori应用，用于触发采购申请API。最终成果是一个在线商店应用，客户可以订购商品并在其中创建新的采购申请项目

 

教程步骤：

1.后端开发：

CDS视图数据模型创建

  • 基于CDS视图定义数据模型，为购买申请应用提供数据基础 [3]
  • 创建购物车数据表和相关字段，定义商品信息、数量、价格等关键属性
  • 建立数据关联关系，确保数据完整性和业务逻辑正确性

RAP业务对象开发

  • 创建自定义业务对象以实现业务逻辑
  • 实现购买申请API触发功能，处理商品订购和申请单创建逻辑
  • 配置业务对象行为，包括创建、更新、删除等操作

OData服务生成与激活

  • 通过自动暴露功能生成OData服务，为前端应用提供数据接口
  • 在SAP Gateway系统中激活OData服务，确保服务可被前端调用
  • 配置服务权限和访问控制，保障数据安全

至此，数据表，数据模型，后端逻辑和供前端访问的接口都已经开发好并部署好

2.前端开发：

Fiori应用开发

  • 采用BTP上的SAP Business Application Studio开发Fiori代码
  • 选择List Report Page模板，配置数据源为已创建的OData服务
  • 设置应用基本属性，包括名称、描述和部署配置

前端部署配置

  • 配置Fiori部署目标为ABAP系统的SAP UI5 ABAP Repository
  • 指定包名和传输请求，确保应用正确部署到目标系统
  • 验证Fiori代码是否已经部署到BSP库

至此，前端代码以及和后端的对应关系也已经开发好并部署好

3.权限和访问配置

配置身份权限，配置OData服务访问权限

建立业务目录，将IAM应用分配给相应的业务角色

发布业务目录，使最终用户能够访问应用

 

看完整个开发流程，你应该明白了：

- 后端开发：写的是ABAP代码，部署在S/4HANA系统内

- 前端开发：标准的Fiori开发，同样部署在系统内

- 权限配置：完整的ABAP权限体系

 

所谓的"限制"实际上是"规范"，就像高速公路有护栏不是为了阻止你开车，而是让你开得更快更安全。

 

结论：真相大白

经过完整的技术剖析和实战案例，答案很清楚：SAP ERP公有云版支持体内的ABAP开发，从数据建模到界面开发，从业务逻辑到系统部署，一个都不少。

所谓的"限制"其实是"升级保险"——让你的定制代码在SAP系统演进中始终保持兼容，而不是成为技术债务。

SAP ERP公有云版 = 能开发 + 更安全 + 可持续

 

关于本文内容有任何问题或见解，欢迎在评论区留下你的想法

Best,
Benedict

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Thanks, Lakshmipathi!

This isn't a consignment business. The material was sold, supplied (for now only virtually) and invoiced in SAP.

After the materials are delivered and invoiced, they must remain in our company's custody, in our warehouse, until the customer has space to receive it. Since the material is very expensive and not just a single unit, it's necessary for us to maintain visible control in SAP of each material and unit once we make the "virtual" supply to the customer. As the ownership is transferred in SAP, the control must be done off our accounting books, knowing how many units of each material we still have, what was physically delivered (how many units and when), once the material has really left our warehouse.

Hours after writing my question here, I was informed that the material has already been invoiced to the customer, so now we need to perform outbound delivery and goods issue, and then “re-enter” all that material into SAP ASAP, to be able to do the already explained control in SAP.

Someone told me over the weekend that a special “customer plant” must be created, but I'm not sure if this is the correct/best way to do it (*) and then, how the material should be entered into SAP so that it's handled the way I explain above.

(*)= If it's correct, I also don't know what’s special I need to request for the plant to be created correctly, so the material is visible and handled/tracked as non-valued (once it leaves our books in SAP).

entry.title: Re: Mvt type 601 does not check the minimum remaining she...
entry.content:
Dear @25103678,

What you’re seeing is actually standard Public Cloud behawior:

  • The Set Expiration Date Check(101913) in CBC is designed for goods receipts / stock increases, not for pure goods issues
  • Movement 602 (RE goods deliv. rev.) increases stock again so system treats it like a new goods receipt, so it checks minimum remaining shelf life and throws message „Shortfall of X days against remaining shelf life in current item (X Day)” if the material is below the threshold.
  • Movement 601 reduces stock no new stock is created, so the standard minimum remaining shelf life check is not called, even if you maintained Entry and check for this movement type.

Documentation below:

 

My proposal, if you really need a hard block at MVT:601 in Public Cloud, use Badi:

  1. Open Custom Logic app.
  2. Create an implementation for BADI_MMIM_CHECK_MATDOC_ITEM

 

  1. In your logic:
    • Run only for:
      • Movement type = 601
      • Relevant plants / storage locations
    • Get:
      • Posting date from the material document item.
      • Shelf-life expiration date from the item
      • Minimum Remaining Shelf Life from product master
    • If SLED < posting_date + min_rem_shelf_life THEN raise an error message.
  2. Result: GI 601 is blocked by your custom check, even though SAP standard SLED check does not run there

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Hire Template Configuration: Supported MDF Object Types and Implementation Guidelines for Onboar
entry.content:
@B-Ajaikaran

I have a slightly different perspective on the effective date setting.

  • Data Model Conflict: I believe using a different effective date setting implies mapping to a different Metadata Framework (MDF) object. Directly matching distinct MDF objects between Onboarding and Employee Central (EC) isn't typically supported out-of-the-box.

  • Proposed Solution: A more viable workaround would be to use the Integration Center to facilitate the data transfer and necessary transformation.

By the way, hope that SAP could incorporate background information into the Hire Template in the coming release😣. This would streamline the complete hire process significantly!

entry.title: Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management
entry.content:
Over the past months Early Adopter Care program participants, were gradually ramped up with additional capabilities powered by the Embedded IoT platform. With SAP Asset Performance Management 2511, we have released the Embedded IoT functionality within SAP Asset Performance Management to all our customers and partners. Customers now benefit from an end-to-end offering that spans from sensor to process action or insights, all within SAP Asset Performance Management - achieving seamless integration of data sources and monitoring of IoT-connected assets, towards establishing condition based maintenance practices.

How does this look

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains 5 new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the IoT platform. Let's briefly run through those apps below.

 

Manage Devices

This helps you connect and manage devices efficiently. It offers a unified platform to onboard, monitor, configure, and control IoT devices throughout their lifecycle—including definition of device protocols, software & configuration management, and more, depending on the capabilities of the connected device or gateway. Many industrial environments use lightweight messaging protocols (e.g., MQTT) to collect telemetry data from machines, devices, and sensors. Embedded IoT now makes it easy to ingest and process this data as it arrives, rather than waiting for batch uploads.

With a new persona, the Device Integration Engineer, customers can now onboard, configure, and monitor devices - capabilities that were not offered in the past and were covered in other systems out side of SAP Asset Performance Management. This opens up new opportunities to get closer to the source of data, or even retrofit installing sensors that are required for maintenance purposes.

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage IoT Dashboards

For near real-time insights and reporting, the Cockpit gives you the flexibility and tools to manage and monitor device data, creating widget-based reports for individual or groups of devices. With this feature, reliability engineers can now access personalised, live, contextual IoT dashboards - unifying sensor data and events - so they detect anomalies immediately on critical assets, flexibly visualize data per their needs, and assist in driving fact-based maintenance decisions.

To quickly get started with a live data feed and exemplary dashboards, you can connect your smartphone in just a minute and explore. See how in the video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Manage Streaming Analytics

Streaming Rules enable enhanced condition monitoring with flow-based models to process time series data in near real-time at individual data point level. This allows for monitoring within the IoT platform, to derive new indicator values, and also triggering of rules within SAP Asset Performance Management. This continuous, real-time feedback loop allows reliability engineers to respond proactively to critical events and implement monitoring and dashboards themselves using low-code tools — capabilities not possible with batch-based monitoring. For more details, have a look at the What's new blog from the 2510 release.

 

For a quick glimpse in how it is working, you can watch this video:

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

Map Devices to Technical Objects

To use the time series for asset management purposes, the sensors from the IoT platform need to be contextualized into the asset semantics using the Digital Twin Manager. The application allows to map devices and their sensors (the OT world) to their corresponding technical objects and indicators from SAP Asset Performance Management (the IT world). Once the connection is established, data is automatically made available into charts, rules engine, and stored into the data lake from SAP Asset Performance Management.

Navigate to technical objects along the technical object hierarchy

Assign measurements from a device to an indicator

For more info, watch this space for more articles to come, and refer to the SAP Help Portal to check out the official docs for getting started.

IoT Platform Administration

Users seamlessly navigate to the applications with out-of-box configured Single Sign-On, and also for data archiving (see Digital Twin Manager), everything is setup automatically. However, some configurations are still relevant for Administrators and can be configured in the IoT Platform Administration application. Examples are the data forwarding between systems, or configuration of Certificate Authorities for device certificates administrators. With the Data Broker, administrators can now setup continuous data feeds between landscapes, i.e. to achieve a near real-time data ingestion into quality / test environments based on incoming data from the production environment.

What's next

Please stay tuned over the next weeks as we publish more articles showcasing the respective capabilities. You can't wait to get started? Check out this recently published blog that describes a brief end-to-end scenario from sensor to insight, using a free simulator app for your mobile phone. See how quick it is to monitor asset conditions, define failure thresholds, and generate maintenance requests using SAP Asset Performance Management.

entry.title: LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) Implementation - Data Transfer to new Standard Fields
entry.content:
When implementing LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC) for the first time, you notice that some field mappings have hardcoded fields from SuccessFactors Recruiting, which cannot be modified to other fields. This happens because there's backend mapping between LinkedIn and SuccessFactors for certain fields. As LinkedIn expects to receive certain values for specific fields, an internal mapping defines how each value is sent. As a result, it is not possible to change the mapping to other Recruiting fields.

You can find the full list of field mappings and whether each one is editable here: Field Mapping Information

For example, industries and employmentStatus from LinkedIn are mapping to industry and classificationType accordingly in Recruiting, and the mapping cannot be changed.

This requirement can create implementation challenges, as some fields linked to these mappings are not used by customers, and they may have other standard or custom fields where the same information is stored.

This blog explains how to move the existing data into the fields required for the mapping using Integration Center. For example, if a customer does not use the employmentStatus standard field but has another field with the same information, they must still map and fill employmentStatus to implement LinkedIn Recruiter System Connect (RSC).

NOTES:

  • This integration needs experience with Integration Center and Recruiting configuration, and it is meant to be handled by Implementation Partners or Admin Users who have an implementation background;
  • The integration described below may behave in different ways on different systems. Please make sure to test all steps in a lower environment before moving anything to Production;
    • For better results, we suggest testing first with a small number of records before updating all of them.
  • Integration Center may not support updating all records in one single run if the number is higher than the tool's limit. We strongly recommend reviewing Integration Center limits before creating the integration: 2742107 - Integration Center: Frequently asked questions
  • As a best practice, avoid creating one integration for more than one field mapping, as this may cause performance timeouts.

STEPS:

  1. Go to Admin Center > Integration Center > My Integrations;
  2. "+ Create" button > More Integration Types;
  3. Select the following setup:
    • Trigger: Scheduled
    • Destination: SuccessFactors
    • Source: SuccessFactors
    • Format: OData v2
  4. Select the entity;
      • For Candidate Profile entity, you can use the entity CandidateLight to bypass required field validation
      • For Job Application, you can refer to the KBA Required attribute on Application fields via OData API - Recruiting Management
      • For Job Requisition, you can add the property "isDraft" to the mapping, making sure to pass TRUE. With this value, you can make your update without providing all mandatory values on the Job Requisition.
    • If the following criteria is not meet, the update may fail.
  5. On "Options" tab, fill all necessary fields
  6. On "Configure Fields" tab:
    1. Change the view to "Field Mapping View"
    2. Link the source field with the new standard field; - For example, you are mapping your existing standard OR custom fields that holds up the Employment Category to employmentStatus field, you need to link the existing field from the left column to the employmentStatus field in the right column. Here's an example from the columns (The entity here is Candidate):
      You need to drag and drop the field.
    3. Repeat the same steps to the ID field by linking the field from the left column to the right column
      • IDs per entity:
        • Candidate ID - candidateId
        • Job Application ID - applicationId
        • Job Requisition ID - jobReqId
    4. Once the mapping is done go to "Filter and Sort" and exclude any anonymized record, otherwise the system will considered anonymized records, which don't support updates:
      1. Click on "Browse" button
      2. Entity Tree View > Select the "Anonymized Flag"
      3. Add and filter by 0 (0 is the value for "Non-Anonymized)
    5. You can skip the "Scheduling" tab as the integration is meant to be executed one time only;
    6. "Review and Run" tab:
      • Click on "Run Now"
      • Wait the integration to complete
      • Verify any possible errors and fix

entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content: Thanks, Lakshmipathi! This isn't a consignment business. The material was sold, supplied (for now only virtually) and invoiced in SAP. After the materials are delivered and invoiced, they must remain in our company's custody in our warehouse until the customer has space to receive it. Since the material is very expensive and not just a single unit, it's necessary for us to maintain visible control in SAP of each material and unit once we make the "virtual" supply to the customer. As the ownership is transferred in SAP, the control must be done off our accounting books, know how many units of each material we still have, what was physically delivered (and how many units), once the material has really left our warehouse. Hours after writing my question here, I was informed that the material has already been invoiced to the customer, so now we need to perform outbound delivery and goods issue, and then “re-enter” all that material into SAP ASAP, to be able to do the already explained control in SAP. Some one told me over the weekend a special “customer plant” must be created, But I'm not sure if this is the correct way to do it (*) and then how the material should be entered into SAP so that it's handled the way I explain above. (*)= If it's correct, I also don't know what’s special I need to request for the plant to be created correctly and for the material is visible and handled/tracked as non-valued.
